column24: and I've got the theme song stuck in my head again.\n\nLife is like a hurricane

reviewText:
DuckTales Remastered is a great throwback to when games were platforming platformers where you formed plats. Seriously though, this remake is bright and vibrant compared to the original NES game. The gameplay is not too difficult (no matter what others may say) and there are a few issues here and there.

For example, others complain about the cane pogo stick not working at times. I find that the times that the cane pogo stick doesn't work is when you are close to an edge. Not all edges mind you, just most of them. In one of my videos, you can see where I hit a block and destroyed it and the block above it did not fall down. Okay, okay. Maybe that is just one of the NES game's quirks. However, then I swing my cane at the empty space below the floating block and then it comes falling down?

Doesn't really make sense, but hey it's a game about a bazillionaire talking duck... so there's that.

Basically, pick this game up. It's great gameplay and fun colors are more amusing than strangling a Webby duck.

PS: The original voice of Scrooge McDuck does the voice here as well. Congrats to 93 year old Alan Young and I hope to God you do the voices for a DuckTales 2 Remastered!

reviewText: I must admit this was purely a nostalgia buy because of my fondness for the movie.  Who wouldn't want to swim in a vault full of treasure?  Never played the NES version so I can't say if this version is easier or harder my guess would be easier since older games are typically more challenging.  The visuals look great and the music is quite catchy, you even have the option to play the original 8 bit music.  It was a little challenging at first but after a few playthroughs it wasn't too tough of a platformer.  I love the fact that they had the original voice actors who were still alive to do this, and it is quite a roster of cartoon legends.    So basically if you have any good memories of Scrooge McDuck and his pals it is definitely worth the 15 bucks.  For people who have no connection with it, you should wait for a sale since there really isn't much to do beyond playing the game on different difficulty levels.  One straight playthrough took me an hour and a half and that was with finding treasures/extra lives.  Overall an average platformer without the nostalgia factor, a must buy for those who's childhood involved the richest duck in Duckburg.\n\n7/10

reviewText: I never played the game this is a remake of, but I bought this because the original was considered one of the greatest platformers of all time. So is it still anything special by today's standards? Not really. It's a very basic platformer. But still, what it does, it does very well. And being based off the DuckTales TV show, it turns out to be a pretty cute little game (and I do mean little; it's a very short game). The original had little to no plot, but they came up with a completely new story to tie all the levels together and features several of the characters from the show (my only real issue with the story is that at times Scrooge seems to be a bit more of a jerk than he was on the show). Some reviewers who played the original thought the emphasis on story was a downpoint, but for me that may have been my favorite part. Without it, it's just a generic, if pretty fun platformer. Plus, these days it's getting harder and harder than ever to find someone who wants to make something that's just nice, like a video game that doesn't have bloodletting or edginess to it (ironically, if more people were to make games like this they would be the ones being edgy"). So
recommended: I'd say DuckTales is a game worth playing
hoursPlayed: and a kind of game I'd like to see more often."

reviewText:
I've never watched the DuckTales TV show, nor played the original game... but as soon as I saw the trailers I was hyped. The game is a remaster of the NES game DuckTales, with a beautiful new stylised look in HD. Not only that, but it has new modern remixes of the older tunes which sound great. The new cutscenes that were added have full voice acting by the original cast, which is an impressive feat in itself. Alan Young as Scrooge McDuck is still as good as always, and it's a joy to hear his voice acting.

The gameplay itself is exactly the same as the original NES game, which isn't a bad thing. The controls are solid and never feel unresponsive. The game itself feels like a new game, especially to somebody like me with no experience of the original. I found myself loving every moment, and I really connected with the characters and the world they existed in, despite having no experience of DuckTales previously.

My only gripe is the game's length. Despite the new level at the start of the game, the main story is only 2.5 hours long. The good thing is that you can choose to unlock all sorts of concept art and sketches for the game using the money you gain by playing the levels. Replaying levels never gets old, and there's an option to turn off cutscenes automatically if you want to just play the game, and also an option to have the original 8-bit music in the levels. I feel like I'll get many more hours out of the game just for the fun of playing the game.

If you're a fan of the DuckTales TV show, or the video game, you must get the game now. If you've had no experience with it before, but are interested, I recommend that you wait for a sale and pick it up then, as the length may not be enough to satisfy. Personally, I'm glad to have the game in my library.

reviewText: Dispite what a lot of people would probably believe, this game is not purely a nostalgia title. I, who never played the original title OR watched the show, still thoroughly enjoy it. However it is best to play with a controller because the keyboard layout is slightly confusing. Lastly, the collectibles in the mansion feel a bit shoved in at last moment. Probably because they were.\n\nFour stars out of five.

reviewText:
This review is mostly aimed at those who enjoyed the DuckTales NES game and cartoon, as I did, because I won't be able to objectively divorce my review from my nostalgic love of this game.

Score: 9/10

This game was made for us.  And, by us, I mean we people who grew up with DuckTales, both the original game(s) and cartoon, both.  I really don't think there are words for how gratifying it is to see the adventures of Scrooge in all the remastered glory that this reimagining of a timeless classic has managed to provide, but I'm going to give it a shot.

First, the graphics.  Not every game should strive for photorealism, and DuckTales is a perfect example of one such game.  As a licensed game depicting a cartoon, I have almost zero complaints about WayForward's presentation here.  It truly feels like you're both watching the cartoon adaptation of the game, while still being very involved in its progression, as the player.  Backgrounds are beautiful, and while mostly static, they do an excellent job of immersing the player in the cartoon world in which the characters reside.  Animations are fluid, sprites are beautiful, and everything looks familiar, and yet brand new.

Second, the music.  DuckTales had exceptional music even when you had to play it on the NES to get your fix, so the team that was tasked with remixing and rescoring this game really had big shoes to fill, but they didn't disappoint.  Every song is reminiscent of its 8-bit counterpart, which is to be expected of a remake.  Not all remixes are made equal, mind you, and some are clearly better than others, but that's not to say that there are any bad songs in this game (in my opinion).  Some music is so good that I had to stop to enjoy it at the start of its respective level (looking at you, Moon Theme, and Mt. Vesuvius theme).

Third, the gameplay.  The gameplay is largely unchanged from the original NES game, but that's not necessarily a complaint.  Some levels are just as unforgiving as their original counterparts, but the game itself is easier in general, due to some quality-of-life changes made by WayForward.  These changes include being able to save progress in between levels, or simply being kicked back to level select upon losing all of your lives, as opposed to having to completely start over from square one.  Having something to spend your hard-earned money on is a new gameplay element as well, which may lead you to make stupid decisions in certain levels while trying to find every hidden diamond (I sure did).

Fourth, and possibly the most importantly, the cutscenes.  The biggest thing that WayForward added to this game is this considerable source of exposition.  When you played the original NES game, there was no backstory given or reason delineated for why Scrooge was doing what he was doing, other than greed (which is not entirely out of character).  The cutscenes provide that important missing element, which really, was the only thing that I found wanting about the original DuckTales.  The voicework is wonderful.  The incomparable Alan Young, who is well into his nineties now, does a masterful job of reprising his role as Scrooge McDuck, and much of the original cast also returns to bring life to this amazing game.  Perhaps the most important detail about the cutscenes, though, is that they're entirely optional.  This stops them from getting stale for those of us that plan on playing this game several times over.

Scrooge, Huey, Dewey, Louie, Webby, Mrs. Beakley, Launchpad, Bubba, Gyro, Fenton, the Beagle Boys, Flintheart Glomgold, and Magica De Spell are waiting to greet you once again.  What are you waiting for?

reviewText:
As someone who grew up playing the original on NES and its cousin on the Game Boy, I was pretty excited for this game, especially when they announced it would be on PC/Steam. Plenty of decent reviews out there, so I'll limit mine to bulleted pros/cons that really stood out for me:
Pros:
-Devs stayed true to the exceptional controls, music, and level design of the original game, and with a facelift that made it look like the cartoon show, it was doubly nostalgic for me. Loved the voice acting.
-The two additional stages from the original game - the Money Bin and Vesuvius - are fun, though the latter far more so than the former. Especially where Vesuvius was concerned though, I wanted more.
-Boss battles were all great fun.
-You can swim in the Money Bin. Not the game's strongest point, but I've wanted to be able to do that since I got the original game when I was 10.
Cons:
-I really would have liked more or different stages. I would hope that if this game is a financial success, that they'd consider making another with more original level designs.
-Cutscenes. I liked the attempt at a bigger story, and that story isn't actually bad, but the cutscenes are long, boring, and with all the wonders they did with the graphics, it would have been nice to seem more gestures, lips moving, etc.
-At an MSRP of $15, it's a little too short, especially since much of the game is material many of us have played before. Might be worth it if you're a big fan, but for the casual platform fan, I'd wait for sales.

Overall, it's worth a look if you're either a huge DuckTales fan, or if it's on sale, looking for a fun game to spend a weekend with.

reviewText:
This is a really good game with the same 8-bit thrill I used to have with NES-clone many years ago.
100% met my expectations.
I can tell this firmly after having completed the game.

Good:
+Just like it used to be and has to be: fun and joyfull gameplay; neither long, nor short; nice background story properly integrated within the game progress.
+Runs alright on low-end systems if you slightly lower the resolution and screen filtering (I have laptop with integrated 128 Mb video memory, 3GB RAM and Intel Core2 Duo @ 2 GHZ CPU and I have experienced very seldom framerate drops)
+Can be played on keyboard, gamepad is not a must at all
+Great escalation curve - the game is gradually becoming challenging but never becomes stressfull
+100% family friendly
+Good secrets and achievements system - you don't have to spend hours for fruitless attempts to keep discovering secret ares and unlocking achievements. Maps layouts in general are very smart in this respect.
Good community guides are already avaliable to fascilitate the progress.

Can't call it 'bad', probably 'minor flaws' will answer it better:
- can't skip dialogues or speed them up (at least I've failed to do so). But is it a serious isse?

Would recommend for causual players, platformer and cartoon enthusiasts, and for sure to take a new look at nostalgia themes.

reviewText:
I liked this one. It's a remake of the classic NES Ducktales game, which was a really good title back in the day.

The game is pretty loyal to the original. It reuses a lot of the old enemies featured in the original, giving them a 21st century makeover with some really nice looking 2D drawn graphics. Also featured heavily is the famous pogo stick mechanic which stood out in the original version. It adds a lot to the game and it's fun to do.

Ducktales is very rich in Ducktales lore. It features many of the characters from the show and there's a storyline behind the whole game that's told in a series of voice acted cutscenes. Amongst the voice actors is Alan Young who voiced Scrooge McDuck in the original cartoon, too.

The game isn't very long and doesn't take much effort to beat. I imagine it'd be a great title for kids to play. However I did play it through on Easy mode as I was looking to enjoy it rather than punish myself with a tough play through. It may take longer and be more frustrating on the higher difficulty settings.

In terms of replayability, if you're not interested in trying or you started out at the harder difficulties, then there's a fun little side quest to do where you use the money you earn whilst playing each level to buy art work and music. It's a nice little extra but it isn't essential to getting the most out of the game either. The art work is mainly concept work. There's an entire gallery dedicated to the characters of the game, which features how they used to look in 8-bit form in the old game. I thought this was a nice touch.

If you liked the original, or Ducktales in general, I'd recommend you check it out for sure. If you haven't played the original and don't care for Ducktales, I'd still recommend checking it out if you can get it at a cheap price as it's a fun standalone game.

reviewText: It's a cute game. Recommended if you played the original for the gameboy. Otherwise, I would only recommend this on sale. The graphics are nice, the difficulty level is actually still quite high (for modern games) but at least they added a respawn instead of the old instant death gameover. Still not really a game for kids. Graphics are fine, music is great, voice acting on point. Unfortunately it won't take you more than 2-3 hours to finish and the replay value is zero. In fact the only thing you can do is unlock a few gallery pics, sounds and to fill the treasury by collecting more money. But the levels are all the same and it will take you more than 5 playthroughs to see a visible difference in the collected money and gold. Play it once, spare yourself the perfection.

reviewText:
I liked this one. It's a remake of the classic NES Ducktales game, which was a really good title back in the day.

The game is pretty loyal to the original. It reuses a lot of the old enemies featured in the original, giving them a 21st century makeover with some really nice looking 2D drawn graphics. Also featured heavily is the famous pogo stick mechanic which stood out in the original version. It adds a lot to the game and it's fun to do.

Ducktales is very rich in Ducktales lore. It features many of the characters from the show and there's a storyline behind the whole game that's told in a series of voice acted cutscenes. Amongst the voice actors is Alan Young who voiced Scrooge McDuck in the original cartoon, too.

The game isn't very long and doesn't take much effort to beat. I imagine it'd be a great title for kids to play. However I did play it through on Easy mode as I was looking to enjoy it rather than punish myself with a tough play through. It may take longer and be more frustrating on the higher difficulty settings.

In terms of replayability, if you're not interested in trying or you started out at the harder difficulties, then there's a fun little side quest to do where you use the money you earn whilst playing each level to buy art work and music. It's a nice little extra but it isn't essential to getting the most out of the game either. The art work is mainly concept work. There's an entire gallery dedicated to the characters of the game, which features how they used to look in 8-bit form in the old game. I thought this was a nice touch.

If you liked the original, or Ducktales in general, I'd recommend you check it out for sure. If you haven't played the original and don't care for Ducktales, I'd still recommend checking it out if you can get it at a cheap price as it's a fun standalone game.

reviewText:
DuckTales: Remastered - I finished the whole game today and MAN it was amazing! Capcom said if this game will be a success they will continue to remake other long gone disney games, including my most favorite, Aladdin, that I used to play on SNES like 19 years ago. And sure DuckTales: Remastered is successful, alright.

I barely ran into any bugs, though. The game is pretty hard, despite dodging the traps and enemies is devastating at some parts. The amount of secrets and challenge in this game is high. Collect diamonds to earn money and unlock from art gallery to soundtracks. The soundtrack is just great, especially the final level before fighting the boss. Some of it is a lot like Megaman, though.

I really recommend this to get started and be prepared for the next
remastered disney games that are on their way to empty our wallets.

reviewText: Not a bad game just has the classic issues of being an over animated platformer from the 90's. Your hit box is way bigger than you think it is. Most of the time  the hit box for a character is inside a sprite or model. In this game it surrounds the whole sprite . So walking or jumping into things that you think you won't take damange from happens till you get used to it. Also the games design could have been better at teaching you when you should normal jump and when you should pogo jump, there are no sections that teach you this. You are just expected to die and learn.\n\nOther than those issues, the game captures the style and feel of the cartoon it is based on. They went as far as to get the original voice actors to make this feel like an episode of Duck Tales. I also really enjoyed the backgrounds since they really take after the Carl Barks comics. Overall I recommend this game.

reviewText:
Ducktales wasn't a complicated game in 1989 and that remains the same now. You have a pogo cane to bounce your way through stages, open chests, stomp gorillas and then some. Controls are tight and the platforming is simple without being boring though higher difficulties don't amount to anything more than taking extra damage and having less health upgrades to find. I just really like bouncing around.

This isn't exactly a long game either with a total of seven stages (the first of which is really just a tutorial stage) but if you're really into collecting art galleries and stage music, then there's enough of that to require multiple playthroughs so you can save the cash to do so.

Presentation is obviously the game's selling point for all of you nostalgic folk. Excellent sprite work coupled with original voice acting from the cartoon series gives you just about the most authentic translation from cartoon to video game you could ask for. Also diving into the money pool is super rad.

No in game volume control though? What's up with that?

reviewText:
One can not describe the amount of nostalgia this game creates when you here that catchy DuckTales theme tune.

The game, what is there to say. It kicks so much ♥♥♥. From the level designs to the enemy roster and boss battles, this game has everything you would expect or want from a side scrolling puzzle-adventure.  Remastering this game was unexpected, but definitely a smart move. And adding  additional content, such as artwork and music is a great addition to the game.

Overall, I would rate the game a terrific 9/10 and would absolutely recommend it to everyone who likes classic side scrolling action-adventure games.

reviewText:
I'm halfway through the game as I write this. Although I've played DuckTales 2 on the NES as a kid, I've never played the original version of its sequel. So even though nostalgia wasn't a big part of it, I'm glad to report I still find this game entertaining (and even challenging at times). However, I do have a couple of complaints:

1. The 2D character sprites look great but they do not fit in well with the rest of the art (backgrounds, chests, gems, etc.), which is unfortunately 3D. IMO, they should've kept everything in the iconic cartoon style of the Donald Duck universe. This is by far my biggest gripe with the game.

2. At the time of writing, I'm aware of two major bugs:
(a) The level is not reset when you respawn. Hence, the baddies will continue doing whatever they were up to when you lost your previous life. This is unfortunate, as it means that losing your first hit point may be unavoidable. And while bosses do indeed respawn, their effects do not (e.g., if you die at the wrong time during the fight with the boss in the Amazon, the ground might still be shaking from when it slammed into it before).
(b) Lots of people report that the game crashes for them when they reach the final boss. I don't know whether it will be the case for me as well but I thought I'd give you a heads up.

3. Even though they were probably never a part of the original version, they should've added special-case animations for talking characters. It's a little silly to see them talk with their mouths closed.

That said, I'm hoping for a remastered version of DuckTales 2.

Cheers,
Bogdan

reviewText:
WARNING! CONTAINS SPOILERS!

My old review of this game was short and flawed, and now that i've replayed it, i decided to make a better review.

Ducktales Remastered is a remake of the Ducktales NES game, made by Capcom and released in 1990. The game is fondly remembered, and for good reasons. The music is great, the level design is good, and most importantly, it had great gameplay. Now, does the remake justify the original, or is it just a failure? Let's see.

Story: The story is the same as the original NES game, but it has been expanded, for the better. For example, in the original game, on the moon level, Scrooge McDuck could appareantly survive just fine without a suit. In Remastered, it's finally explained, he chews oxygen flavoured taffy. Not to mention the final level has been changed from Transylvania to Mount Vesuvius in Italy, Magicka's home. Overall, the story fits the game perfectly. 9/10.

Graphics: The graphics are well-made as well. You could say the game is 2.5D, the characters are drawn in 2D, but the levels are drawn in 3D (but can only be traversed in 2D). Overall, WayForward and Capcom did a great job at the graphics. 10/10.

Gameplay: The gameplay is largely the same as the NES game, with a few changes. The pogo jumo is now easier to perform, but you can change it to the same way it's performed in the original game (hard pogo in the settings). Overall, the gameplay is solid and fun. 9/10.

Music: The music has, of course been remixed for the remake. And the composer have done an excellent job at the music, every track feels nostalgic and new at the same time. Not to mention, in case you're really nostalgic, yu can unlock the option of replacing the remixed soundtrack with the 8-bit versions of the tracks (you have to beat the game ocne first though). 10/10.

In conclusion, Ducktales Remastered makes the original NES game justice. It's by no means the best video game remake i've played in my life, but it deserves a spot on the shelf (or your steam library).

Written by Littlefoot, the gaming dinosaur.

reviewText:
Steam Library Playthrough Update:

Last night I finished game #11 - Ducktales: Remastered.

The first thing I noted was how gorgeous this game looks - the art is extremely crisp and clean, and it really feels like an interactive version of the TV show.

Apart from the art, I also really enjoyed the gameplay - the platforming was solid and the controls were responsive and satisfying. I particularly liked the pogo" mechanic which allowed you to bounce of objects and reach otherwise inaccessible places.

I have two main complaints about the game however - one is that the cutscenes are very long
recommended: and despite featuring the original voice cast of the TV show
hoursPlayed: the voice acting is annoying. I found myself skipping through most of the cutscenes because I couldn't take the voice acting anymore.\n\nThe other (more minor) complaint is that the game was quite short for its $14.99 price tag
voteText: working out to $2.49 per level. I got the game on sale
votesHelpful: but had I paid full price for the game
votesTotal: I would have been unsatisfied with the amount of content.\n\nRating: 75%"

reviewText: DucktTales: Remastered is a fairly good game that for the most part captures the awesome that was in the NES version.  There is alot of changes in this game.  The story is more fleshed out in a good way, it almost feels like a long lost Ducktales cartoon episode (with faithful voice acting included.) Its been awhile since I've played the NES DuckTales, but I swear the level design on some of the levels have changed as well, with even some added new levels at the beginning of the game and somewhat at the end.  I will say that the controls don't feel near as tight as the old verison, but not bad enough to not recommend the game.  One thing they did nail is music. MAN did they do a good job with the updated tunes, especially with the Moon stage and Boss music!  All and all if you played the NES Ducktales or have enjoyed watching Ducktales in the past, this game hits the spot!

reviewText:
I actually have the original NES version of this game sitting in a shelf behind me. This was one of my favorite NES games when i was a child. At the time the cartoon was very popular over here in Sweden so there was no surprise that even the game did well.

I was a bit worried at first when i saw that they were making a HD remake of a childhood memory. The first videos i saw made me go in to a nerdrage over how soulless the game seemed to be. It honestly looked like a crappy flashversion of my favorite game. But when i saw it for a good price on GMG i had to have it in my collection, just so i could say i hated it, which i diden't.

This is a really really good remake of the classic game. The graphics, even if they were very different from the original, still felt really good. The controls were spot on as with the original and the music, oh my god the music. It is said that you dont mess with the classics, but the composers handled the original soundtrack with the outmost respect and made new classics of them.

The new additions in gameplay also worked pretty well. They had to redesign some of the levels and for the most part it worked preetty good. The only downside is the mandatory tutorial level in the very beginning of the game. It's irritating when you are trying to beat the game for a second or third time, or when achivement hunting.

But overall this ia a great game. They really gave the respect needed for such a classic game and made our old gamer hearts fill with a warm feeling of nostalgia.

reviewText: Classic game gets a facelift! Fans of the original nes version of this game, fans of the series, and anyone just wanting to try something fun will not be disappointed. This is the same game you once loved, with some new bells and whistles. Aesthetically perfect, with new cut scenes to add depth to unanswered questions from the original. The original soundtrack has been redone, and sounds fantastic...and they got most of the original voice actors from the cartoon to reprise their roles for this version. All in all... it looks great, sounds great, and most importantly plays great.

reviewText:
Pros: If you love the original Capcom NES DuckTales game, you will LOVE DusckTales: Remastered! Just the remakes of the music alone will send chills of nostalgia up your spine. The addition of in-game cinematics starring the original cast of the TV show make each level like a mini episode, including Scrooge (Alan Young - age 94) and Magica (June Foray - age 96). The game is quite an ugrade form it's original.Each level has been expanded based on the original game and all the characters and enemies are beautifully recreated in 2D Cell style animation agianst cool 3D level backdrops. The game also has extra levels, bosses that have been expanded to include new attacks based on their originals, and bonus extras to unlock like Art and Music from this and the original game. Though a sale price is always nice, this game is totally worth the retail price tag for fans of the original NES DuckTales.

Cons: This game crashes more than Launchpad McQuack, usually at the start of a level or during a final cutscene. The crashes usually just cause the application to fail and quit but I beat the game on Easy and Hard mode and both times, during the final cutscene right after Magica and Glomgold fly off into the clouds, the screen goes black and continues to play music until it sounds like a broken record and locks up the PC entirely (Shift+Tab, Windows+D, and ctrl+alt+del fail to respond and a hard shutdown/restart are required). This may be my PC alone, even though my gaming PC is on par with a PS3, but it's hard to tell.

Since the crashes don't happen during gameplay and may only be an issue with some computers, I would still recomend it with a solid 7/10, totally worth retail.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros: If you love the original Capcom NES DuckTales game, you will LOVE DusckTales: Remastered! Just the remakes of the music alone will send chills of nostalgia up your spine. The addition of in-game cinematics starring the original cast of the TV show make each level like a mini episode, including Scrooge (Alan Young - age 94) and Magica (June Foray - age 96). The game is quite an ugrade form it's original.Each level has been expanded based on the original game and all the characters and enemies are beautifully recreated in 2D Cell style animation agianst cool 3D level backdrops. The game also has extra levels, bosses that have been expanded to include new attacks based on their originals, and bonus extras to unlock like Art and Music from this and the original game. Though a sale price is always nice, this game is totally worth the retail price tag for fans of the original NES DuckTales.

Cons: This game crashes more than Launchpad McQuack, usually at the start of a level or during a final cutscene. The crashes usually just cause the application to fail and quit but I beat the game on Easy and Hard mode and both times, during the final cutscene right after Magica and Glomgold fly off into the clouds, the screen goes black and continues to play music until it sounds like a broken record and locks up the PC entirely (Shift+Tab, Windows+D, and ctrl+alt+del fail to respond and a hard shutdown/restart are required). This may be my PC alone, even though my gaming PC is on par with a PS3, but it's hard to tell.

Since the crashes don't happen during gameplay and may only be an issue with some computers, I would still recomend it with a solid 7/10, totally worth retail.

reviewText:
The game itself is pretty damn impressive. The graphical quality, real voice actors, music, cutscenes and enjoyable gameplay is quite worth buying it. But that's where the good parts for this game end.

As most of the people have stated out, there is a crash bug in this game at the very last boss of the game. It has to do with some drivers by NVIDIA, pretty much, since I did beat this game on my old laptop back when I played it when it was brand new. However, owning my own PC with NVIDIA drivers installed does seem to make this game not worth owning, unless you want to keep repeating the very first five levels of the game.

So in the end, I would give this game 9/10 for the nostalgia, but leave the 1/10 because of the crash bug. Good try, should've tried to fix it, though.

reviewText: Ducktales Remastered is the return to Duckburg for one mission. To relive youre childhood but will it succeed or will it fail miserably ? In Ducktales Remastered you play as Scrooge Mcduckand one day the Beagle boys raid your mansion for a treasure map which leads to all kinds of treasure so you gotta go and find all the treasure. The game is played like a metroidvania type game where you can explore the level all you like with platforming mixed into the mix. As the Remastered says in the title its a remake of the classic Nes version. The update is worth while. It has charming visuals which and fantastic music to go along with it. The game plays great and it is one of the best game out there. But like every game it has a few problems that make the game pretty hard to play. A few glitches can be found that make you stuck in the platforms. The game also has some pretty hard platforming sections and it you need to have plan a perfect jump or you will plumit to youre doom. But the game is pretty solid. It has a charming style which you cant deny and fun levels and overall the fans of DuckTales will simply love this game. Its a trip down Memory lane which you want to expierence. I give DuckTales Remastered a 7.5/10

reviewText:
I was very doubtful about this game when seeing footage and hearing the musics, I thought the art style and the musics weren't so good.

But I have to say that once playing it I wasn't disappointed it at all.
Everything is great: the art looks wonderful (everything from sprite, their animations and the backgrounds) and most of the musics are really good too. The only music which wasn't so good was the Himalaya theme because they added too much stuff to it with different new rythm and meldoies which completely hide the original melody and make it sound like it's 2 musics in one.

The game has the 5 original stages but re-vamped with new areas to make them longer as well as a new intro and final stage. The new intro stage hardly matters though because it's very short and straightforward.
Gameplay is perfect Duck Tales fun and I liked how they kept the pogo mechanic from DT2 (you don't have to press Down to perform a pogo jump).

The cutscenes are no problem. On the contrary they share the Duck Tales sprite, they're even funny at times and it's a pleasure to hear the original voice actors.
You can skip them all anyway if they really bother you.
The only cutscenes which bothered me a little was in the Amazon stage because you have to pick 8 different items throughout the stage and there is a small cutscene for each of them which is a bit too much (but again, you can skip that).

In-game play time said 2h45 after I beat it but it actually took me around 4hours. The relative shortness is justified by the low price.
Also there is tons of cool artwork to unlock if you want to 100% the game which is very rewarding (if you look at Wario Land Shake Dimension, a very comparable game, beating the game 100% wasn't rewarding at all).

This game is everything we'd hope for a remake.
But that's the only problem for me: I wouldn't have wanted a remake of DT1. I would have prefered a remake of DT2, or even better, a whole new DT game. I guess I'll have to content myself with the couple of DT2 references thrown in...

reviewText:
This review was going to be about how I had never played the original Ducktales and how this game made me love losing, instead, I have to talk about the technical deficiencies of one of the best platformers I've ever played.

When I first started the game, it had ludicrously bad framerate. I didn't understand at first. It looks like a 2D flash game for god sakes. I tried lowering the resolution, tried turning off the anti aliasing.

Nothing.

Turns out in some weird form of programming, the game is tied to your desktop. Specifically the AERO theme. I had it disabled on my copy of Windows 7 64bit, and this drastically affected the game as a result. Turning it back on was no big deal and the game ran at the framerate I expected in the first place.

If only that was the end of it.

The finale of the game (which is rightfully the trickiest part of the game) ends with two big middle fingers. First, the final boss will crash the game. Imagine going through that hell of a stage, seeing the finish line and having it cut short thanks to shoddy programming. The way to fix it of course if you're on a multicore is to start up task manager and setting the affinity of the game to 1 core. With that done... the game still crashes.

Yes, even after all that, the game still crashes. After you defeat the boss, his death cutscene will for some reason, crash the game. I don't know why. I really don't. I had to resort to skipping the cutscene to prevent it.

Imagine not only having finally beaten the boss, but for it to also crash right after, and that's still not the other middle finger.

Right after that hard stage and that hard boss, you're thrown into TWO instant death scenarios.

So imagine on the Hard difficulty, you defeat the final boss without getting hit once and have 3 lives left, only to lose them all to some of the cheapest, gotchya" moments ever. Mega Man X3 had a similar ending and it wasn't even close to as punishing as this.

So despite the game and the programming throwing every single setback they could

reviewText: Ahh, DuckTales: Remastered. Just as a sidenote, I never did play the first one on the SNES. But yeah, as a Disney fan and generally wanting to play light-hearted cartoon-y games a lot, I was excited for this one. Having it gifted to me, I decided to hop straight into this and found that the presentation was fantastic. The visuals are top-notch, pretty much having been remade for this HD remake of the first game, and the music even better. With a New Game option awaiting me, I decided to go for that (and picked Easy mode, mind you!) but went back to explore the other menus later; there waiting for you to pick is a Gallery of sorts, which can also be accessed via the main game's world hub"/level selector. Options for game configuration are there and play time. That

reviewText: I had the original game on the old-school original Nintendo system when I was a kid and played it over and over.  It was a great game.  I was a bit apprehensive when I saw that they re-made it.  However, they did a great job with the re-make.  It's not exacly like the original but it has most of the same elements and it successfuly captures the feel (and the fun) of the original game.  I saw some people on the discussion boards griping about some glitches in the game when it first came out.  However I just now got the game (it's been out for several months now) and I'm having no problems whatsoever.  So I'm assuming the game has been updated/patched and the problems have been solved.\nAnyhow, my only complaint is that game seems a little short.  I've been playing for only a few hours and I'm already more than half-way through it.  But it's super-fun, so I feel it was still totally worth buying...especially since I got it on sale.  I'm having a blast playing it.  Enjoy!

reviewText: Great remake. The graphics, voice acting, sound and animation are superb. Its a fun game that holds up even in 2014. I died to the 1st boss 3 times, I am not the best at platformers, but decent, so it is a good challenge, not too easy at all and has selectable difficulty. They added new cutscenes and a ton of bonuses to unlock as well. I got this on sale and it was one of the best deals I got this winter, if you see it on sale pick it up, I recomend it at sale price for sure!

reviewText:
This game is actually a pretty damn good remake. It's still as fun as the original and the gameplay is still the same. This game is still pretty difficult if you haven't played it before but its easy once you know the game inside and out.

Now if you're wondering about whats different
The changes they made are:
2 new levels
Cutscenes with the original voice actors
Unlockable art and music
Some changes to levels to get rid of the multiple visits to the Transylvania level
Remastered music
Better grayfics with hand drawn sprites in a 3d world

Overall, its a good remake of a game you should play if you like a good 2d platformer

8/10

reviewText:
Oh boy oh boy, it's the time of the year where I re-make bad reviews I did in the past.

This game is incredibly good. Good soundtrack, greatly made.

It has nice cutscenes and the overall 2.5D thing is awesome.

However, it has it's bad sides.

Let's begin:

Somewhat kinda boring I guess map parts. I played this, it was great but sometimes it just gets boring. It's my personal opinion so you can check out the game if you disagree with me.

Crappy keyboard support. Again, it's my personal opinion, however I do not know if it was my keyboard being a pile of trash or the game isn't good for keyboards at all. I would definitely recommend playing this with a controller.

This review was quite short. Please give constructive criticism, if you don't think it's a good game, please give reasonable reasons why you don't like it on the comments, same applies if you think my review isn't good.

reviewText:
Во-первых, стоит иметь ввиду, что у многих настольгия осталась именно по второй части. А тут мы имеем ремейк первой, которая примитивнее второй, с её магазинчиком, апгрейдами и поисками карт. Поэтому почуствовать себя эдаким перепончатолапым Индианой Джонсом не выйдет.

Что понраивлось:
- старый добрый геймлей: прыгаем на клюке, пинаем ящики - всё как в старые недобрые 90'ые. Даже глюки перенесли с любовью =)))
- уровни немного изменили и расширили, добавили немного новых... сюжет тоже немного переработали.
- музыкальные темы перезаписали, но сохранили
- графика довольно приятная
- изменили механику боссов - некоторые стали гораздо интереснее и сложнее

Что не понравилось:
- убрали дополнительные сокровища... приходишь на место старого секрета, а там ничего кроме алмазов и пополнения здоровья
- смысла в поисках секретов и зарабатывании бабла особо нет - если только открывать унылые и вряд ли кому-то нужные концепт-арты на ачивку
- тупые детские диалоги, которые возникают по кажому поводу и без повода... Мало того, что просаживают темп игры, так ещё и сбрасываются только через меню
- играть на клавиатуре не то чтобы прям уж очень тяжело... но, если учесть, что 75% игры проходится с зажатыми двумя кнопками, проблемы с подкючением геймпада весьма не порадовали.

Ещё немного мыслей.
Непонятно, на какую аудиторию расчитывали разработчики. Детям игра будет вряд ли интересна, потому что и Утиные истории" для них уже не актуальны
date: и проектов по-лучше хватает. Если на взрослую аудиторию
recommended: на зачем было делать её НАСТОЛЬКО детской? Диалоги примитивны (о том
hoursPlayed: что они вообще не нужны уже писалось) и шутки тупы даже для детей... Сгодятся разве что совсем для трёхлетних. На настольгии игра тоже играет весьма частично. С одной стороны знакомые уровни
voteText: знакомая механика... но всё какое-то чужое (нет
votesHelpful: запущенная под эмулятором игра по-прежнему доставляет).\n\nИтого
votesTotal: брать или нет. Я рекомендую купить. Как минимум в надежде на то
votesFunny: что игра окупится и разработчики примутся за ремейк второй части."

reviewText:
Childhood nostalgia at it's finest, very fun game that can be enjoyed even too this day. With the HD-remake, DuckTales returns us to the Amazons, the Himalayas and so on, even the moon. All together with know characters of the series including GizmoDuck, there is a lot of fun content packed into the game.

If you loved the game or even if u had bad luck and missed out on this gem, then here's your chance to enjoy it !

4/5 - There are a few flaws with the game and concept but most games around it's release-date had some.

reviewText: Twenty four years later and Scrooge McDuck is back in this fantastic HD remake of one of the most iconic games on the NES. You and your nephews will once again explore each corner of the world (and the moon) to find valuable treasure armed with a pogo cane and a beak to sniff out riches! Enjoy the original voice cast from the TV show and experience the fun of diving in a vault full of money! Relive the magic, you never know you may solve a mystery or rewrite history.

reviewText: I have to admit to not having played the original. I'm also not generally a big fan of retro games, but this was a lot of fun. Its got a sort of simplified Metroid-vania thing going on... Its quite short, but did (pleasantly) remind me of the Megadrive days. Perhaps grab it in the sale!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you absolutely adored old licensed Capcom platformers from the NES/SNES/Genesis eras, then there's not a lot to think about here, This game is for you.

DuckTales: Remastered is perfect if you wanna relive those old memories with a new coat of paint, some updated tunes, and some of the kinks of progressing through the game worked out. It's the same hop and bop adventure you remember back then, only bigger and better. As for what this game may offer those not familiar with those older games or DuckTales itself, beyond the simple joys (I mean VERY simple) of hopping and bopping enemies and collecting treasures for a larger score, it may be best to wait for a sale.

While DuckTales Remastered offers a solid recreation of the original game and is genuinely fun if you're up for something simple, the project just doesn't feel like WayForward went quite far enough in trying to make the project truly shine in the same ways that GRiN's Bionic Commando: Re-Armed succeeded. I won't call it lazy, because there's a clear love of the material here with the sprite work, reworked soundtrack, and tracking down all the original voice actors and actresses. At the same time, it does feel like the game had a lack of ambition, time, funds, or all of the above.

reviewText:
Das Spiel sieht gut aus, die Musik ist gut, auch wenn ich das Original besser finde.
Leider mag ich dieses Spiel aber nicht. Ducktales ist einer meiner Lieblings 2d Jump and Runs.
Das Spiel ist eine Beleidigung. Es sieht aus wie Ducktales, es hört sich an wie Ducktales, es spielt sich aber nicht wie Ducktales. Man kann zwar immer noch den Stab der reichen Ente benutzt, allerdings hat man das Leveldesign verändert.
Das wofür ducktales bekannt war, waren die vielen Geheimnisse und Abkürzungen. Diese wurden komplett gestrichen. Man findet immernoch kleinere Geheimnisse, die Abkürzungen existieren aber nicht mehr. Ein Metroid Eskes Jump and Run mit der Ducktales Lizens wurde dadurch zu einem liniares Erlebnis, das langweiliger/ banaler nicht sein könnte.

♥♥♥♥ you, Wayforward, ♥♥♥♥ you, Capcom and ♥♥♥♥ you, Ducktales Remastered!

reviewText: I like the remake. I played the first one as a kid on the NES, and beat it plenty of times as a rental. there were some parts of the level design in a couple of areas that could have been better, but overall the game is pretty good and as fun as the original. the main issue was the frequent dialogue, lol. I liked it, it just happened a little frequently. There are challenges and leaderboards for the difficulty, loot gathered, and speed runs.  so there is quite a bit of replayability for people in those areas. as a 30-something that played the original as a child, I feel that this is one of the better remakes of classic games.  it's on sale for 50% off, and may have an 80% off day during the sale, so I figured I'd post this in case anyone was on the fence about it. It's a good grab.\n\n

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game in every way, but it has two fatal flaws (both purely technical and could easily be solved with a small patch)

1. Fix controller support, it's 2016, no reason to have hard coded xbox controls
2. Fix the crash bug, the game is unable to be completed right now, it crashes 100% of the time on the final boss.  Which is an absolute shame as the new final boss is fantastic.

I really WANT to change this to yes as the music, graphics, and gameplay are all fantastic, and a very good throwback to the NES game (without being the EXACT same game), so if those two problems are ever fixed i'll have to revisit this.

reviewText:
Do you remember Chrismas of 89. I do. It was when I got Duck Tales on the NES. Thats all I did was  play for  the next few weeks. Nostalgia. It was one of the best titles on the NES. Duck Tales was one of the more creative games on the system and along with Little Nemo they take me back to when I was a kid... So they remade Duck Tales. Good.
the good. First the music is great, and the voice work of the orginial cast of the show is very very cool. The game play is mostly untouched so thats nice and the controls feel tight. The graphics are cell now and look like the show. So for a 2D remake it has excelled in presentation. But...
The negitves are minor but annoying. The dialog. Ehh... You will listen to at times two minutes of dialog. This wouldn't bother me but most of the time it is in the middle of the game. You can not just speed by it either. So the game comes to a stop, where as the orginal was nonstop. Infact there are other slight changes as well. Rather than collecting enough money to progress you will have to collect things instead. Another thing is this game is much easier. The NES had a difficulty curve to most of its games. Duck Tales was one of the easiest games on the system. This remake is much easier. I never died. I fired up my NES and yeah I died here and there. It's not the Remakes fault but a modern controller and more health pick ups do make it easier.  This isn't hold your hand easy, but not hard. Oh and theres unlocks, cause of course.
The theres the reports of Nvidia cards freezing at the end. I got through it no problem.
This is a good game. Really good. It reminded me more of why I liked the show as well as the NES game. It does a lot right and does not stray to much from the orginial which is nice. The orginal is still my favorite, but I like this a lot. I dought they will remake Duck Tales 2, but one can hope. Personally I would rather see a Little Nemo remake, but thats just wishful thinking. Now no matter what I do I can not for the life of me get the Duck Tales song out of my head.

reviewText:
There's nothing mastered about this game. It is nostalgia packaged with original voice acting from the cartoon, cheap 3D art for the environment and nice looking 2D art and animation for the characters.
And that's exactly the problem with this game; it can't decide wether or not it should poke at your nostalgia from the TV cartoon, or from the NES video game so it decides to go for both.

Seeing that this is an actual video game, I would've prefered if they spent more thought into the actual game elements and less so with the dozens of character conversations which is forced on the player.
It is fortunate that you have the ability to skip 'cinematics', you do however feel less so when you have to replay a level, and then skip the three consecutive cinematics the game just has to deliver to you in order to get back to playing the actual game.

Wayforward has gone through great lengths to make sure the character controls and level design feels like the NES game, but seems to have forgotten to ask if the old game actually had good level design and avatar game feel.
Controlling Scrooge McDuck does feel good and precise, but it doesn't matter much when the levels themselves are simply annoying.
The character is playing the game to collect treasures, you are motivated to find more and the game has diamonds scattered everywhere.
If you enter a room and theres a corner where there's nothing: there's something there, go there, jump a little and diamonds will appear. The game habitualizes the player to nervously search through every nook and cranny for diamonds all the time. At this point you might as well make them visible to begin with, and not have the player go there, then leave the spot to then have the diamond spawn and then finally go back to the spot to pick it up. It's tedious, it breaks flow.

And that's essentially what the game's biggest flaw is; it doesn't understand flow. All the running around, jumping, bouncing and searching for things which the original game did well, gets obscured by useless fluff that's only there to make us remember an old TV cartoon.

reviewText:

I did skip cutscenes, but honestly they add nothing to the game other than ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ exposition. Seriously this game is like 5 levels and then a boss level that is basically just a reskin of one of the other levels.

Why did Crapcom remake this game? This ♥♥♥♥ blows.

One ♥♥♥♥♥ / 10 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

reviewText:
Nice graphics and creative remake of original levels. The music and voice acting are also very nicely done.

The story is boring, and interrupts gameplay way too frequently to keep me immersed in the game experience. Perhaps the designers should've kept the game action going while voice acting happens on top. Since the characters are basically just GIFs with voice acting on top, I'm shocked you can't skip the current line of dialogue without skipping the entire cinematic.
The writing is written for ages 6 - 10, so it's very hard to stay interested in what the characters are talking about.

The game bosses' AI is very simple. Each boss follows a strict pattern and doesn't even take into account Scrooge's position onscreen. This makes every boss battle an exercise in simple pattern recognition. This is expected from the original NES title, but I would've liked to see a remastering" of the challenge from the original game.

The game feels repetitive after the second level is completed. I'd only recommend this for fans of the original show

reviewText: 24 years later and still looks amazing. Duck Tales: Remastered is a blast from the past to any owner of NES. Back when games were amazing and nice to play, WayForward Technologies helps us to relive our happiest moments in one of the most memorable games of all time. Like the title suggests, its obviously remake of original game with better graphics, and updated soundtrack.Plus to original remastered in glorious HD levels we get also 2 additional levels for story progression. While in NES version there wasn't that of a story, here we get like a lost TV episode, with original cast from the show itself. While story can be just simple to understand it shouldnt be taken too seriously because its children show, so nothing serious or be amazed with. But most important part is redesign of original 5 levels. They are all back and looking better than ever. In addition the original soundtrack also is back with some addtions which makes it much better. We are used to the fact some games are being re-released as HD but in this case we get a bit more.You can also unlock some arts and other stuff if you are interested, or even swilm in Scrooge gold vault like he does in TV show. Now all we need for total nostalgia happines is 2nd Duck tales game from NES and maybe remake of Chip n Dale just for fun. If you didn't play original NES game, take this one. Its our childhood and looks at it's finest. 9/10.- Dima Voronovich, Russian Pro reviewer.

reviewText:
I got this game solely because I really liked the Gameboy version back in the days.

- So far I played it all the way through within <4hrs. If you think of buying it you should consider the remarkably short playtime.
- The controls are quite poor. (same for the controller support)
- At a certain point the gameplay is just frustrating since the blurry graphics with thick outline simply don't fit with the pixel-precise mechanics (you can stand on an edge but pogo jumping is impossible) / Nevertheless that worked for the gameboy version when the graphics matches the pixel-precise mechanics
- The cutscenes.... I don't know whose idea it was but he possibly got shot after the game was released. Although there is a possibility to skip the so-called cinematics but skipping for of them just to get from one level to another is simply annoying

I liked the gameboy version when I was a kid - so I thought buying this one here would be a good idea.... was not...

Artwork is great since I like the ducktales, soundtrack is ok when played in 8-bit. As for the rest... please let professionals do the work next time - people are paying money to play this.

reviewText: I hate it to say it, I really do. But this game is NOT woth picking up for full price. Honestly I wouldn't go much higher than 5$. Why? For all the prettyness and great voice talent in the game, the game sufferes from 2 majors flaws. 1. The hitboxes for both you and anything that can damage you is horrible. You can be just slightly off from hitting a foe directly on their head and take damage. This is made worse by the amount of 1-hit deaths in the game. 2. The games controls are terrible. This ruins the game for me. Its tragic just how bad they are when you see the depth the game has to it. How are they bad? They are unresponsive. One secound you are holding the pogo button bouncing along, and for no apparent reason you stop and will most likely die or take damage. You won't always jump or move when you want to as well. This made even the fun parts of the game a nightmare. Instead of enjoying myself I found myself watching my every step. The game has so much going for it but I can't reccomend it for 15$ when it just isn't polished.

reviewText:
Everything in this game that's from the original is wonderful, especially the remastered music and the controls.

Everything in this game that they added which wasn't in the original game is horrible. This includes:
- A pointless tutorial level
- Horrible writing
- Annoying voice acting
- A final level that takes place *after* the final boss and is so difficult and finnicky that I couldn't get past it and wound up ragequitting because I was literally seconds away from finishing but couldn't make it there. I probably died about 50x more in that final sequence than I did during the entire rest of the game, and never got the satisfacting of beating the game. Thanks WayForward.

reviewText: Great license and nice remake. However the game was never an innovative platformer and that did not change. The level design is very linear with little variation in the gameplay. It is also a little unfair in certain spots to artificially increase the difficulty. At the end of the remake you can buy art, music and more from the money you collected during the game. This is a nice feature but for me not enough to replay the game. Also I miss the possiblility to switch to the original 8bit graphics as possible in the remastered Monkey Island games. In total, it was nice to play it again but more for sentimental reasons. People looking for good platformer and want to do so with  Disney figures  better buy Castle of Illusion" which is a much better jump-and-run.\n"

reviewText:
This game is a hot mess. The level designs from the original game are still as great as they ever were but every other thing in this game actively makes it worse than the original.

It has this bizarre art style. Really detailed, well animated drawn sprites moving over ♥♥♥♥ing garbage simple 3d maps. It looks kind of like Paper Mario except it's actually appropriate for that game and is more skillfully done. This minor quibble is nothing compared to...

THE VOICE ACTING! What the ♥♥♥♥? Scrooge's voice actor must have been mumbling 5 feet away from the microphone. Everyone else comes through crystal clear, but the main ♥♥♥♥ing character sounds like garbage. Which is kind of a problem. Because he talks a lot. Actually it might not be a problem because he says the same 5 or so unbelievably lame lines over and over for the entire game and I don't think being able to hear them clearly would actually measurably improve my experience.

Oh, and get ready to mash start because this game has cutscenes piled on top of cutscenes. This is basically the textbook case on how to assassinate a classic NES game by adding all the worst ♥♥♥♥ from modern games to it.

Play the NES version. It's still good. ♥♥♥♥ this remake.

reviewText: I am a huge fan of the old NES game but couldn't care less about the TV series. And that's my main problem with this game. The hillarious amount of cutscenes in it is so high I cannot recommend this to anyone.\nYou have to skip at least 3 cutscenes to get started in a level you selected and even then your gameplay will be interrupted frequently during the level. All of this has no other purpose than to stretch this 2 hour game over the 3 hour mark so the way too high price point doesn't feel so bad.\nJust play the Amazon and by the end of the level you will have seen or skipped over 20 cutscenes. Why do we need those?

reviewText:
Although this game seems to be well done and would be loved by any fan of the NES original(if done the right way), I cannot recommend this game.

Mainly due to the following.

1. The price is a little to high for how short of a game it is.
2. This is the only game I own on steam that does not support my Logitech F310 controller (a very common controller) I refuse to play a platformer using keyboard controls and don't feel like messing with xpadder when I shouldnt' have to.
3. I contacted Capcom support over 2 weeks ago and haven't gotten a response of ANY kind. Not even a Go eff yourself" reply. NOTHING. I've been playing Capcom games for over 25 years
date:
and this is how they treat their customers? lol good luck. I'm unlikely to purchase another game from them.

It's a shame too. I really wanted to enjoy this game.

reviewText:
A lot of cutscenes (can't fast forward - have to skip them to move ahead quicker).
Unresponsive controls. Had the feeling that game can't process multiple key down events (jump, left (hold), up (try grabbing chain) - fails).
Achievements tied to replaying the game multiple times (besides them, this game has low replayability value).
Unskippable ending credits.

Overall it is hard to recommend.

reviewText: The Beagles Boys had the crossed the line too far. They kidnapped his nephews, roughed up his money bin, and, worst of all, were having a treasure hunt without him. Scrooge McDuck would sit idly by no longer. Everyone told Scrooge that he wasn’t relevant anymore; it’s been over twenty years since Duck Tales and kids these days liked voxel zombie rogue-likes and Disney is only interested in mass-producing child stars so Hollywood can have a perpetual source of trainwrecks instead of making cartoons. Scrooge didn’t listen though, he didn’t care. All he wanted was all the swag the world had to offer him and the Beagle Boys’ heads mounted on his mantelpiece and nothing on Earth and the Moon would stop him on his blood-soaked journey. The world may have moved on without him but Scrooge will make sure that no one will ever forget that you never f*ck with a McDuck.\n\nRevised Edit: After playing more of this game I can't recommend it anymore. The final level is godawful and its like WayForward didn't even play test it. Just skip this game, its fun for a while but it pulls a Launchpad and crashes and burns so hard at the end.

reviewText:
Before I got to the last level, I was ready to give this a 6/10. So in my mind, the Metacritic user score of 66/100 isn't that far off. It's difficult to live up to nostalgia, and this game probably was facing unrealistic expectations from the beginning. The game is kind of fun, but it's not particularly challenging once you figure out where all the health pick-ups are. I enjoyed the boss fights, but the platforming elements were a little tedious.

I was getting annoyed in the last level, in particular the last part (don't want to spoil the ending) because I thought it required a ridiculous level of precision. But then I finally realized that using the analog was the problem and switched to the D-pad, all was fine.

Graphics-wise, the characters are beautifully drawn. Unfortunately, the same love and attention wasn't put into the scenes, where some of the things like helicopters look like they were drawn and shaded with Microsoft Word ... not even Microsoft Paint.

The collectibles consist of art and music that can be unlocked through purchases using money you've gathered in each level. Unfortunately, you would need multiple playthroughs to get to the best stuff: the music and TV show art. And I didn't enjoy the game enough to play through more than once, so I was never able to access them.

The unskippable cut scenes were the biggest grip that most people had. The developers added an option to skip them. I will say that the worst part of the cut scenes wasn't that they were unskippable (at the time) ... it's how utterly boring the dialogue was. Seriously, was the show ever that bad?

I have to deduct a point in principle for the unskippable credits, taking the overall rating down to a 5/10. I don't generally mind unskippable credits, but 1) at least making it interesting, and 2) don't include every single person in all of Capcom! Seriously, the credits are obnoxiously long.

reviewText:
If you love the Ducktales franchise, don't bother with what I have to say and get this game - it's really a no-brainer if you are invested in the Ducktales universe.

Now, let us get the positive things out of the way first. The game is pretty good looking, bright & colorful with big sprites and everything. With the exception of the Transylvania-level (which looks really good in the outdoor-parts) backgrounds are a tad bit bland - but overall no complaints about the visuals. Together with the music and the voice-acting (both of which are excellent) you can't argue much about the presentation. It really is that good.

However, what's not so good is the fact that the game has some weird slowdown / micro-stutter every now and then and doesn't seem to run at a consistent speed. Making it feel unresponsive/sluggish at times. The next issue I have is the constant cutscene spam, and the incredibly awkward way of skipping them (you press pause, select skip cutscene and confirm - if another cutscene is triggered right after the one you skipped, you do it all again). The cutscenes are nicely done and all, but I am okay with seeing them one time - especially when I am trying to get something done on hard mode / extreme mode (where you will die at times) this gets old very quickly. Until I noticed you can skip cutscenes, I was actually so put off by this that I was going to uninstall this right away. The cutscenes really take away from the flow and speed of a classic NES title. To give you an example; by the time the Amazonas introductory cutscenes are over I would have actually finished the entire stage in the NES original already.

Which brings me to the next design decision I am not okay with, almost all the level have you gather X items in order to proceed to the level boss. Not only wasn't that in the original - it serves no real purpose other than to slow you down. It's neither fun or exciting in my book. Same goes for a lot of retooling of stages that have altered layouts now - I am not sure I would actually dare to touch anything that was conceived by a good portion of the team behind the original Mega Man, those guys were/are geniusses. The Wayforward people, not so much. The result is a couple of area just feel somewhat off, being more difficult than they used to be.

My biggest complaint is that the game doesn't feel NES-like enough when you actually play - I don't know what it is, but whenever I play the NES original or the Gameboy version everything feels tighter, more precise. There is definitely some weird stuff going on with hitdetection, I have been hit by spikes while still standing or jumping from a solid block right next to a spike-pit, it isn't funny anymore. Visually though, you can't tell that you would get hit - there is no indication that the hitbox on the spikes is that enormous. Generally I am having more trouble hitting stuff with the pogojump too, compared to the original. Generally speaking, everything feels a bit off.

To sum it up, everything Wayforward added or changed made the game somewhat worse than the 25 year old original. They should have looked at Bionic Command Re:Armed by GRiN which was basically just a cosmetic update with a few convenience-options added it but kept the game pretty much as it was. Wayforward however remastered" Ducktales by adding clutter no one asked for that ends up breaking the beautiful simplicity of the original.

As said above
date: if you love Ducktales the TV show - get this; but if you enjoyed the original game for reasons like simplicity
hoursPlayed: flow or generally enjoy classic console games consider yourself warned. Instead of Ducktales Remastered I definitely will be hooking up the NES whenever I feel like going on a treasure hunt with Scrooge McDuck again."
voteText: February 16, 2014

reviewText:
I had my eye on DuckTales Remastered for awhile now, since I loved the NES game so much. Well it was on sale this week so I decided to pick it up and I don't regret it.

It's a great nostalgic throw back to a franchise many of us 80's and 90's children grew up with. The music has been remastered wonderfully and I haven't had any problems with the controls. It's great that they managed to get (most?) of the voice actors back, that only make's it that much more special.

The stages are mostly left the same, with minior changes to make it more action packed or intresting, I haven't had a problem with the stages, in my opinion it simply makes the whole experience more refreshing".

A complaint that seemed common with people was that the cut scenes cut away from the game and while agree that sometimes there's a little bit TOO much banter interuppting gameplay

reviewText:
This game is painful. As someone with fond memories of the original product from my childhood, all I can say of this newer experience is that the developers did too good a job copying the original game... right down to the mechanics from 1990.

That just happens to be something you really, really should not do. Nobody wants to have games today like we used to in the 90's. There are no saves; The hit boxes are unforgiving as all hell; The game pulls super annyoing and unfair tricks on you all the god damn time.
The only way you get through this game is by trying, and dying, a LOT. And starting from the very beginning, every single time. In a word, this game is hard. But it is not hard in the good challenging sense. It is hard in the frustratingly unfair, hair-pulling, rage-inducing sense.

Also annoying: Too plentiful and slow-paced cutscenes that you have to rewatch every single time, although you can also skip them every single time.

That said, it is beautiful to watch and listen to. But I know it's not something I'll be coming back to.
WayForward focused on the wrong things to upgrade for 2013, and it's a shame.
voteText: 25 of 73 people (34%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I loved the DuckTales cartoon in the 1980s and so I hoped I'd like this remastered version of the original NES DuckTales game. Unfortunately, the developer failed to understand the current market and decided to design the game as if it were an NES game. Essentially, a lesson in frustration.

First, you can't save whenever and wherever you want. I realize many games do this today, but it's a poor design choice. All it does is increase the overall level of frustration and repetition in a game. We've had the capability to save our games when and where we wanted since 1984 (see King's Quest), yet in 2013, it's a rarity because game developers are lazy.

Second, the controls are awkward and that's even using a gamepad. The pogo jump, for instance, is hit-or-miss and rarely works right when you're attempting to do it over spikes or some other deadly landmass.

Third, it seems half the damn game is cutscenes. Don't get me wrong, I like a good story as I grew up on classic Sierra Online and LucasArts Adventure games, but these cutscenes are unskippable and the story involved is barely adequate, even for a game based on a cartoon.

[EDIT - I've been informed that cutscenes are now skippable. I don't know if this is a recent development or not, but considering I couldn't skip them, the above paragraph is remaining. That said, this factor should no longer be held against the game if cutscenes are indeed skippable.]

Now I know some people will say I'm being unfair, as this game is essentially a remake of the NES title. To them I reply: Deal with it. This isn't the same game. Yes, it's a remastered version, but it's not the same.

Changes have been made in every step of development, so there's no reason why a real save game mechanism, skippable cutscenes and a decent control scheme couldn't have made it into the works. Saying the NES game was like this is a poor argument, because the NES title had hardware limitations that modern consoles and PC do not.

So what's good about this game? Well, it's DuckTales (which I imagine means something to you if you bought it) and the original voice actors have come back to play the parts they did in the cartoon. In addition, for those who wanted a near-perfect replication of the NES title, this is a masterpiece.

In the end, I have to say I don't recommend this game. It's not terrible (I've certainly played worse), but it's very frustrating. While I'm sure that'll bring some gamers to a near ♥♥♥♥♥♥ state, it's far more likely that same level of frustration will drive most gamers away.

reviewText:
DuckTales: Remastered is a game I went into with no experience of the previous NES classic, I was aware of the original but aside from brief mentions to it in episodes of AVGN and other unorthodox gamers, I never got to appreciate the NES original. Therefore, my view on this game is entirely based on my experience with this version alone.

'DT:R' is a very hard game to review in my opinion, as it certainly felt like a classic NES side-scroller with some strong gameplay, bosses and challenges very reminiscent of the NES days - however, I found the controls (for the Xbox controller at least), to be somewhat frustrating. The controls aren't particularly responsive and can lead to very unfair deaths and lost lives (an example being on thorny ground, when you pogo over it but accidentally slip up and lose a life, then cannot jump properly until you lose immunity, hence meaning you lose another life). It's moments like these which really ruined 'DT:R' for me personally.

The cutscenes are quite a drag. Fans of the TV show may really enjoy them as I'm certain they are very true representations of the actual characters, however for me, the humour is for the most-part very cringey and I feel like the cutscenes really do interrupt the gameplay. This is a nitpick, but another thing which bothers me is the fact that the cutscenes 1. do not have a clear 'skip' button, you have to select 'start' then 'skip cinematic', 2. are strangely animated, despite looking great, the lack of mouth movement and over-usage of only a number of animations really bothered me as sometimes Scrooge would look grumpy for no apparent reason.

The design for the levels really lets down the game in my opinion. The constantly respawning enemies and the ropes really bothered me whilst playing. The ropes are your means of climbing, however can sometimes be unresponsive and work very differently to ropes/vines in other games such as Rayman Advance. However, the levels do look great for the most part, even if the first level has some very repetitive backgrounds that you wish they could do more with. The characters look magnificent and all are immediately recognisable to their TV counterparts. Likewise, the design of the hub where you choose levels also works really well, with endearing cutscenes every single time that are enjoyable to watch, until you've had to watch hem more than once.

'DT:R' is a challenge by no doubts, as were many games in the NES library. However, I found that the difficulty came from trying to handle the controls, rather than the actual challenges that were presented to me (aside from the ghosts that you cant kill, screw them). The bosses are challenging and will take you several attempts, however, once again I blame the number of attempts I took when killing the Amazon boss entirely on the odd controls.

Overall, 'DuckTales: Remastered' is a game I would only recommend 100% if it is nostalgic for you. Whilst I would recommend 'DT:R' to anyone who enjoys side-scrollers and challenges, this game seems to cater more towards those who were either fans of the original NES game or the TV show itself. DuckTales: Remastered is by no means a bad game, but I don't know whether I would call it a good game either - enjoyable, yes, but the controls and level design let it down big time for me personally.

Overall: 2/4

reviewText: I don't really understand why this is is sitting on a 66/100 metascore. Are there times the controls can be frustrating? Yes. Are there times when you aren't sure what's going on with hit detection? Yes. Will you ragequit after flawlessly navigating Vesuvius, the boss fight, and the first portion of the end-game escape sequence only to find yourself completely unable to jump rope to rope due to the control issues? Almost certainly.\n\nBut that's part of the charm. It's just like the NES version, but prettier, with a more glorious soundtrack, lots of extra media goodies, and a full money-bin of nostalgia. It won't be the best game you've ever played, or the longest, but it's charming, fun, and has a lot to offer. It's certainly better than the passable 66% score would have you believe. Worth checking out, but try to grab it on sale for under $10.

reviewText:
This game right here, this is a masterpiece reincarnated in beautiful HD. I am one of those guys who played Ducktales for the NES back in the day, at least as early as 2002,  When I first found it in my brothers box of old games and shizz. It was fun and all that, though I could never manage to beat any level.

Then I heard that Capcpom was going to remake this game, I almost shát my pants because I wanted to play this game so bad because the cartridge was broken. Boo-hoo.


The story is pretty straight-forward, Scrooge finds this map which shows locations of some treasures. At least you get a backstory to why Scrooge is travelling around the world, unlike the NES version.

The gameplay is superb, you'd better play this game with a gamepad. You hold (X360 controller) X to use the cane as a pogo stick and just, yeah bounce, of course.

The music is pretty good, when you boot up the game it starts with the NES version of the theme song then converts into a remade version, it's catchy as all hell.
Then you have the music from the stages, the best one is the moon theme.
The voice acting is also pretty good. Not much more to say there.

The graphics is charming, it's cartoony, what did you expect from a Ducktales game?

I enjoy this game extremely much, it's not too easy and can actually be rather hard at times, even for experienced platformers.

10/10
