reviewText:
Ducktales Remastered is a fantastic remake of the first Ducktales game that was for the Nintendo Entertainment System back in 1989. The new music sounds great, the gameplay is just as good as it ever was (not to mention you can change the pogo settings to whichever you're more comfortable with), and the cutscenes really captured the spirit of the show, especially since most of the old voice actors reprised their roles.

The difficulty selection is a nice feature for those who either want to just breeze through the game without too much of a problem or jump right into the harder modes that the original NES game was known for. Not to mention that any money that you collect throughout your adventures can be used to purchase things in the gallery such as game artwork, music of the game's soundtrack, to even art from the TV show! Or you can just swim in your earnings in the Money Bin. That works too. Plus, after beating the game at least once, you can play the game with the 8-bit soundtrack, which includes the NES soundtrack and 8-bit versions of the new music added in this game. Though, I'm kinda disappointed that they didn't make an 8-bit version of the Final Boss theme, but oh well.

Overall, Ducktales is definitely a game that I recommend to those looking for a good side-scrolling platformer, those who are Disney/Capcom/WayForward fans, & those who grew up with Ducktales, whether it'd be the show and/or the video games. In any case, I'm going to wait for the day that they'll make another Remastered game based on another hit show from the Disney Afternoon, but only time will tell when that day will come.

reviewText:
Ducktales remastered is a remake of the classic NES game. I’ve never played the original NES game, so even without the nostalgia glasses, I still think Ducktales remastered is a wonderful game with some minor flaws.

The game features a 2.5d look with hand drawn sprites and backgrounds and they look amazing. The redone themes are catchy, memorable, and kickass. They also brought back the original actors to voice the characters. The controls are tight and responsive. There is plenty to unlock with the gems you collect from character art, music, and even sketches from the show.

Some of my minor gripes with the game are the cut scenes are fairly frequent and take you out of the experience. Every time you find an item there’s a cut scene. While you can skip them you have to do so manually, there is no option to skip all cut scenes.

Ducktales also isn’t for everyone. It features the classic NES difficulty if you lose all your lives you have to replay the level from the start. I found the game to be challenging but fair. The game only became frustrating at the very end where you have race to the top.

Overall Ducktales is a great and challenging platforming game that still holds up well after two decades.

reviewText:
DuckTales is one of the most iconic 8-bit games with massive replayability, fantastic music and a wild variety of levels to explore (with hidden areas and treasure). Anybody who's heard of the NES has heard of DuckTales (along with Mega Man and other classics) and to this day it is the best licensed Disney game ever made. Based on the animated series of the same name it wowed fans and gamers (and fans who were gamers) like few others had.

But time moved on and in this new century younger gamers might not be willing to try the original since 8-bit is so old-fashioned, no? Wayforward Studios though (all fans of the original and the animated series) tried their hand at this remake you can obtain here on Steam. In a nutshell, it is perhaps *the* best remake of a game that I have ever played. Like with the original, the controls are tight, the music (though remixed) is still ear-candy and the new additions (levels, voice actors from the animated series, graphical updates etc.) blend incredibly well into the original game's feel.

Sure, some small issues are there (the new final level is kind of a big leap in difficulty among other things),  but there is no possible way to deny that DuckTales Remastered is a fantastic addition to your games library. If you like Mega Man, Shovel Knight and other platforming titles with a bit more to offer than rinse & repeat then this the a game for you. If you grew up with DuckTales (re-runs across the world to this day) then you'll love it. With multiple unlockable objects, tracks and what not there's a good challenge in it as well.

Enough of my yakking, get the game. If its on sale, buy another copy for a friend.

reviewText:
This game right here, this is a masterpiece reincarnated in beautiful HD. I am one of those guys who played Ducktales for the NES back in the day, at least as early as 2002,  When I first found it in my brothers box of old games and shizz. It was fun and all that, though I could never manage to beat any level.

Then I heard that Capcpom was going to remake this game, I almost shát my pants because I wanted to play this game so bad because the cartridge was broken. Boo-hoo.


The story is pretty straight-forward, Scrooge finds this map which shows locations of some treasures. At least you get a backstory to why Scrooge is travelling around the world, unlike the NES version.

The gameplay is superb, you'd better play this game with a gamepad. You hold (X360 controller) X to use the cane as a pogo stick and just, yeah bounce, of course.

The music is pretty good, when you boot up the game it starts with the NES version of the theme song then converts into a remade version, it's catchy as all hell.
Then you have the music from the stages, the best one is the moon theme.
The voice acting is also pretty good. Not much more to say there.

The graphics is charming, it's cartoony, what did you expect from a Ducktales game?

I enjoy this game extremely much, it's not too easy and can actually be rather hard at times, even for experienced platformers.

10/10

reviewText:
It definitely plays like an old NES game, albeit with shiny new graphics and music.  The game's not a port; rather, it's more of a reimagined version of the original game.  This new one has a new intro stage, new end stage, and gives a bit of a wider variety of objectives to accomplish in each stage.  Maps appear in easy and normal mode to help you with the objectives, but they're absent in hard and extreme modes.

I'm actually astonished they got all the original survivng voice actors to reprise their roles.  Especially the VA for Scrooge McDuck.  That man's like over ninety years old!  What devotion!

Really, if you like Shovel Knight, I think you'd like this game.  Shovel Knight draws inspiration from the original, as well as from Mega Man (both Ducktales and Mega Man were developed by Capcom).

reviewText:
To hell with the mixed reviews critics have been giving this game. To hell, I say! I found this reimagination of the classic NES DuckTales game to be a delightful and nostalgic adventure, invoking memories of when I played the game originally as well as memories of watching the cartoon on the Disney Afternoon.

The game was given a complete visual overhaul, with HD levels and backgrounds, fully animated character sprites, and wonderful use of effects and depth. The five original levels return, able to be played in any order! You no longer need to backtrack to other levels to open new areas once you'd found a certain item, which I imagine is to ease the confusion this caused in the original. The boss battles have been completely revamped, making full use of the environment around you. In addition, there is also a brand new final level that tests your mastery of the platforming mechanics.

The music for each level has been remixed, bringing the 8-bit classics up to date and giving them a much more orchestral feel. Another new feature is added storylines and cinematic sequences for each level, complete with full voice acting by most of the original cast of the television series. There's also extras and unlockables, like the in-game art gallery where you can unlock various rewards such as concept art and animation stills.

The developers put a lot of thought into these features, giving the players the option to use them or lose them in order to forge their own DuckTales experience. Don't like the new cinematics? You can skip them in the pause menu. Want to hear the old 8-bit soundtrack? There's an option for that. I think that WayForward has done an excellent job with creatively blending the NES game and the cartoon together. Whether you're a diehard fan of the original or a newbie looking to try it for the first time, DuckTales: Remastered is a much-appreciated remake that is truly worth its weight in gold.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Ducktales Remastered is a remade version of the classic Ducktales video game from 1989. I didn't remember much of anything about the game or the show when playing, so anyone who's afraid that this game is purely nostalgia-driven can worry no longer. As for anyone who has played the original, I'm not sure how much stuff is new/old.
Ducktales Remastered is a classic platformer where your main goals are to make it to the end of a stage as well as collect as much money that appears as you can (you use this to buy art and music). Your moveset consists of pogoing on your cane (which jumps higher, nulls ground hazards, and can be used to attack) and hitting things from the side with your cane. Despite these basic controls, the game does a good job to employ them in the levels.
The game is fairly short, consisting of seven levels. But on my first time, the game took me several hours. The game as a whole looks beautiful. There are plenty of nooks and crannies to scramble around to collect gems, and I think the levels are well-designed overall. Each level even has different items in chests and the like depending of difficulty. The remastered music for each level is beautiful, but you can still listen to the original, 8-bit versions if you want.
Throughout the entire game, there are a bunch of cutscenes. And while the animations are fairly limited in these, they compliment the original voice-actors' voices. It feels like you're playing through an interactive DuckTales episode with each new level you visit. They're definitely charming and I've caught myself rewatching a few in future playthroughs. If you DIDN'T want to watch them again, you can chose to have most of the cutscenes skipped in future playthroughs. Scrooge also says a few lines throughout the game that are also charming albeit a bit annoying after multiple times.
As far as difficulty goes, the entire game seems balanced up until The End. You're given four difficulties: Easy, Medium, Hard and Extreme. Easy gives infinite lives and you take half-hearts in damage while the others have lives and you take full hearts of damage. Extreme has no saves throughout the entire game, so if you Game Over, you have to restart. I recommend starting on Hard if not Easy, since Medium was harder due to little/no life drops.
Now we get to my one huge problem with the game. The game stays at a nice level of difficulty throughout most of the game (some levels have tough bits, some bosses can cause trouble, etc). However, there are two segments after the final boss that I spent nearly two hours on trying to beat alone. First, there's this really tight upwards chase scene where you're likely to screw up a lot. Every time you lose the race, you lose a life. THEN, there's a segment where you need to quickly climb up ropes to avoid rising lava. However, a lot of the rope grabs are nearly-pixel perfect, and one screw-up means fiery death. Every time you Game Over (with 3-4 lives each chance) from those two points, you need to do the whole last level and final boss AGAIN. And with how unfairly difficult they are, you'll be doing it a lot if you're not on Easy. I refuse to play Extreme for this reason alone! If you don't like the idea of Game Over-ing, I highly recommend Easy first (if you want all achievements, you need to play it anyways for those 2 health upgrades), then moving onto Hard when you're used to everything.
Overall, DuckTales Remastered is a solid game that I would recommend at full price. As awful as it is, I won't let The End's unfairness spoil the rest of the game. I'm sure that, Ducktales fan or not, the game's level designs and mechanics will make any platformer fan happy while the music, art, and cutscenes will make it memorable. Achievement hunters can also rejoice, as the gameplay is severely lengthened if you go for those. It's a great game that I hope people don't skip out on because of the press's overall negative reviews.

reviewText:
Wayforward's attempt to capture the Ducktales magic is a total success, bless me bagpipes!

Being born in the 80s, The Disney afternoon and shows like Ducktales were a big part of my childhood. I played a lot of the capcom Disney games back then, back during a time when a show/movie tie in game had an actual chance of being something good instead of the most cheaply made thing possible to sap money from kids who didn't know better. I played them all; Darkwing Duck, Chip n' Dale, and of course both Ducktales for the NES. These games manged to deliver great fun even when they didn't have a lot to work with. So when a remake was finally announced almost 25 years after the original, I was tense and wondering just how well it would be handled, thankfully my fears were for the most part, needless.

Remastered takes the settings of the original NES game, which its levels were all loosely based on actual Ducktales episodes, and fills in all that was missing from the NES age of limitations. The art is cartoonish and very beautiful. While the 3d on cell shading seems jarring at first, it ends up working very well to make you feel like you are playing in an actual episode. To add to this effect they have added an overall plot. It was hinted at there was an overarching plot in the original but its limitations really didn't let it say much, its now fully backed by dialogue and the insertion of a intro and final stage, the final stage being unique now instead of just revisiting Transylvania. The original 5 stages have been fleshed out to feel like you are playing 5 episodes of the show that are loosely connected into a mini arch like was a common thing to do in the show. Many of the cast makes their various appearances depending on the stage like the nephews, Gyro, Launchpad, Fentin and others, all voiced very well to deliver a great experience. The music in the game is faithful remasters of the original, the only one that is a tad weak is the Transylvania because it gets a bit dub-steppy but in all the music is excellent, and as an added bonus the original 8bit themes are unlockables, including 8bit versions of the new stages.

The only complaint with the game is not one I share but I will note it for those that it may bug. The voices are not by their original actors from the show. It is worth noting that while this bugs purists its not exactly fair to hold it against them as many of the original actors are actually dead or too old to call upon to get the voices. Don't let this minor issue hold an entire game away from you that's great, give this a go. And in a personal opinion, I hope to see more well done remakes like this, Darkwing Duck being at the top of my list with possibly the Ducktales 2 gameplay being next in line.

If you liked the original NES game you will get some nice nostalgia out of this one. It stays true to the original while hotting up the graphics and adds a few extra levels. reviewText:
This remake has a huge nostalgia bonus for those who have played the original title. Still, it's a very decent platformer in its own right. The balance between respecting the original game and introducing new surprises is thought out well. The gameplay remains identical, which is the most important thing.

While all the character designs and animations are excellent, some of the 3D assets can look unfitting. Nevertheless, the graphics are colorful and clear. While the music is good, it sounds like it's trying to pull out a bit too many tricks at a time.

As the focus has been in making an accurate remake, I think the fullest potential could not be extracted out of the resources at hand. Therefore, what I would really love to see next is an original sequel with a more open world.

reviewText: As a staple of my own childhood, DuckTales Remastered is a dream come true. The levels stay incredibly faithful to the original game's design, the graphics are crisp and colorful and the soundtrack is incredible. I would have said that WayForward did an amazing job, had it not been for one major flaw; the hit detection. This has been something that has plagued any retro" style game
date: whether it be remakes of old games or brand new ones. The hit detection in DuckTales is not only poorly presented but also incredibly frustrating. For example
recommended: pogo-ing onto enemies with just outside of their hitbox results in you taking damage
hoursPlayed: even though graphically it shows itself as landing the hit. Another example is during the Amazon boss battle
voteText: there is a segment where his head will fly from the background to the foreground
helpfulPercent: making it tough to discern where he will land/hit
votesHelpful: which results in the loss of a heart. With the old-style sensibility of restarting levels or boss battles once you lose your 3 hearts
votesTotal: this quickly reared its head as this game's Achilles Heel. DuckTales is a personally beloved franchise
votesFunny: be it the game or the show. I still highly recommend this game
commentsCount: but I feel WayForward made a huge mistake with not patching this issue before release."

reviewText:
While the game retains the same gameplay and enjoyment of the original, it has some very giant flaws that I cannot believe or understand how the developers allowed to exist.

The first major flaw is the hit boxes. Either the enemy or Scrooge's hitboxes are way too liberal. Now, I'm not saying it needs to be pixel perfect, but it needs to be within reason of the pixels which, in many places, it is not even remotely close. So the hitboxes are really bad and loose in a lot of places.

The second major flaw is, for enemies that take multiple hits (See bosses), they get an invincibility to them after each damaging hit, which is completely reasonable, however they then become like ghosts and you can move through them. This is bad because often by the time you are getting away or through them, they come back into being solid and then hurt you, all because they don't retain their physical parameters during invicibility. This could have easily been resolved by either giving a shorter invicibility length or by simply making them not become ghost-like on hit.

Other than those two flaws, the game is very fun and quite enjoyable.

reviewText:
This game is great!  I haven't played much of the original but I admire what it was--a brutally hard game with great music and visuals.  Remastered brings it into the 21st century with lots more options and an easier difficulty so you can just play through it and enjoy yourself.

Don't be fooled, though--this game can still be challenging!  Tons of secrets await and for the true collector there is a huge gallery of artwork you can unlock (though it's rather pricey).

The only negatives I can think of are that the cutscenes sometimes become too intrusive and even then, you can just skip them.  The voice acting is great but if the cutscenes had been dialed back, the game would be the better for it.  A definite recommendation.

reviewText:
Alright, I absolutely love hard games. Really, big fan. But there are two types of difficulty: the one that when you lose you feel like you are getting better, on your way to win next time, and the one that is just random, stupid, annoying and sometimes due to unresponsive controls.

Ducktales is more of the second type. There are lots of annoyances for losing, you are sent back to the stage selection screen and you need  to press start and select skip at least 3 times in order to skip the cutscenes you already saw. Plus, you lose all your diamonds, and as a game that encourages the player to explore to find them, it's pretty annoying having to go through the same exploration to get them again. Imagine playing Metroid and losing your upgrades after dying. Sort of closer to that than Mega Man, where you don't actually lose that much, you just go through the linear stage again.

Some stuff are pretty random and require straight-up memorising patterns, and sometimes the controls are not very responsive. I'm not saying it's completely bad, it's just a dated type of difficulty that aged poorly.

Now to the good part, I'm absolutely in love with the boss fights, those are usually the highlights of any game for me, and in this one, they don't disappoint. The level design is pretty good, not amazingly perfect, but good enough. There are a decent amount of secrets throughout each stage, which makes exploring interesting, you'll find yourself searching every inch of the stage for treasures. The environments are PERFECT, I found myself smiling stupidly with every new stage and enemy, everything looks absolutely gorgeous. The soundtrack is also incredible, and that's something I don't usually even notice in games.

Overall I'd say Ducktales Remastered is a decent 2D platformer with top-notch graphics and soundtracks, but prepare to get pretty annoyed after some free-deaths it throws at you.

reviewText: DuckTales: Remastered is one of the best, or perhaps the best platformer I have ever played. It used regular platforming skills, like in Super Mario Bros. but adds twists, by having Scrooge's (the main protagonist) cane as a weapon. You can use the cane to jump on enemies heads, smack items towards enemies, or even use it to jump across dangerous areas. With five different levels to choose from (six once you complete the first five), there is so much to do, plus it is extremely open, so you can choose which way you want to complete the levels (most levels involve in collecting different items). It really is an amazing platformer, and I feel sorry for those who haven't played it. So, I highly recommend you buy this game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I bought Duck Tales: Remastered yesterday, and just completed it today. I have to say, it was a lot of fun. Having not played the original on the NES much I can't comment much on the differences, but I found the old one extremely difficult compared to Remastered. It was made easier by the fluid controls - I didn't have to battle once with it, and if I remember correctly, to perform the pogo on the NES you had to push down and B, whereas on Remastered, as long as you're in the air and press B, the pogo will work. I found this very pleasant. My Xbox 360 controller worked without even having to configure it. I knew I was going to love the game as soon as I was navigating the menus using it.\nI've noticed a lot of negative reviews regarding the cut scenes, but I enjoyed them on my first play through. The animation and voice overs were amazing, and it followed the story from beginning to finish. It was literally like playing an interactive story of Duck Tales, not just a platformer. I heard after a recent update you can actually turn them off, but on your first run through I would recommend keeping them on just so you can see how beautiful this game really is.\nGreat sound, great graphics, dynamic bosses with more than a single move.. this title is a must have for platform lovers and Duck Tale fans alike. While the Capcom special is on it's currently half price - you really have no excuse.

reviewText:
Pretty much perfect. It took the old NES Ducktales game and made it feel like an actual cartoon episode. That's a good thing.

This isn't one of those remakes that turns down the difficulty 99 notches either. If anything, it's more difficult than the original.

I hesitated playing this because I didn't like the 3D effects mixed with the regular 2D animation, but you get used to it pretty quickly and it's easy to accept once you start playing.

It's not a 100% copy-paste remake either. There are all sorts of touches that make it feel like a new experience. One example: in the original game, you'd meet a statue that would force you to pay money to progress in the game. You meet this statue again, let's just say.

Only real quibble I have is sometimes Scrooge says little phrases like up I go!" when you climb a rope
date: and these get repeated a lot.\n\nThis should be an instant buy if you watched the show and played the original NES game. It's fully worth letting your nostalgia buttons be pushed."

reviewText:
Life is like a hurricane...here in Duckburg!...

Not only is this game a lot of fun, it definitely brings me back to childhood. I spent many a happy hour watching DuckTales and when I saw this game, I couldn't resist. I'd played the original when I was a kid and was so sad when we lost the game when we moved.

Imagine my surprise when I saw it was remastered!
Now, I'm pretty sure that we all had the first thought--would it be as good as the original?
Don't worry--it is.
It's better!

The music, the graphics, the familiar faces and names...they're all there and the game is great. It's got Easy, Medium and Hard settings, so you can decide how to play as well, which is a perk to me. Haha. OH and the voice talents are phenominal. I loved hearing Scrooge's witty retorts and Huey, Dewey and Louie's Unca Scrooge!"

All in all--a great game and the nostalgia is wonderful.

And c'mon--I know you're singing the theme song with me now

reviewText:
Ducktales Remastered is a fantastic remake of the first Ducktales game that was for the Nintendo Entertainment System back in 1989. The new music sounds great, the gameplay is just as good as it ever was (not to mention you can change the pogo settings to whichever you're more comfortable with), and the cutscenes really captured the spirit of the show, especially since most of the old voice actors reprised their roles.

The difficulty selection is a nice feature for those who either want to just breeze through the game without too much of a problem or jump right into the harder modes that the original NES game was known for. Not to mention that any money that you collect throughout your adventures can be used to purchase things in the gallery such as game artwork, music of the game's soundtrack, to even art from the TV show! Or you can just swim in your earnings in the Money Bin. That works too. Plus, after beating the game at least once, you can play the game with the 8-bit soundtrack, which includes the NES soundtrack and 8-bit versions of the new music added in this game. Though, I'm kinda disappointed that they didn't make an 8-bit version of the Final Boss theme, but oh well.

Overall, Ducktales is definitely a game that I recommend to those looking for a good side-scrolling platformer, those who are Disney/Capcom/WayForward fans, & those who grew up with Ducktales, whether it'd be the show and/or the video games. In any case, I'm going to wait for the day that they'll make another Remastered game based on another hit show from the Disney Afternoon, but only time will tell when that day will come.

reviewText:
Ducktales remastered is a remake of the classic NES game. I’ve never played the original NES game, so even without the nostalgia glasses, I still think Ducktales remastered is a wonderful game with some minor flaws.

The game features a 2.5d look with hand drawn sprites and backgrounds and they look amazing. The redone themes are catchy, memorable, and kickass. They also brought back the original actors to voice the characters. The controls are tight and responsive. There is plenty to unlock with the gems you collect from character art, music, and even sketches from the show.

Some of my minor gripes with the game are the cut scenes are fairly frequent and take you out of the experience. Every time you find an item there’s a cut scene. While you can skip them you have to do so manually, there is no option to skip all cut scenes.

Ducktales also isn’t for everyone. It features the classic NES difficulty if you lose all your lives you have to replay the level from the start. I found the game to be challenging but fair. The game only became frustrating at the very end where you have race to the top.

Overall Ducktales is a great and challenging platforming game that still holds up well after two decades.

This game is a rollercoster of my childhood memory. As a kid, I grew up playing videogames a lot and Duck Tales is one of my favourite games. So I was really looking forward to the remake.

The remake, however, does not live up to my expectation.

Pros: Enhanced graphic and stuff to buy in game.
Nostalgic memory. It is really nice to hear that catchy intro tune again!
The non-linear stages from NES version is still good as in once was. You could choose whichever stage you like first.

Cons. Quite buggy. I lost my safe THREE times. Not sure how could this happen so I decided to do a marathon to finish it on a single play.
Scrooge is quite unresponsive to control sometimes. Especially the last boss battle where you would need precision.


Conclusion. Buy it if you want a reminiscing moment. Don't buy it if you are new to this

reviewText:
A strong piece of nostalgia. The classic themesong is catchy and will stay with you for days on end.

The gameplay itself basic. A simple platformer from the NES days with a modern touch. Visuals are bright and crisp. The audio is as impressive this time around as it was way back when.

The game is a little short and seems to focus it's replayability around grinding gold to unlock unneeded collectibles such as artwork and soundbytes. While this is saddening, there is only so much one can do with a remake.

Overall, an excellent game that I would recommend for anyone who wants a simple platformer or wants to be brought back to their childhood.

reviewText:
Here's my review of Duck Tales Remastered:

PROS:
-Fun and well controlled gameplay.
-Controlls well with both gamepad and keyboard & mouse.
-Maps/levels are greatly designed and just like the original as far as I've seen.
-Feels a lot like the TV show.
-The game is challenging, giving you a feeling of accomplishment when you finish a level.

CONS:
-The cutscenes can sometimes feel like they're interrupting gameplay.
-Sometimes can be frustratingly difficult.
-I've experienced some graphical glitches like sprites disappearing and reappearing (flashing back and forth)

SUMMARY:
Some people say that this game is inferior to the original on the NES and only worth it for fans of the original, I dissagree. This game is just like the original with added story as far as I've seen. I hadn't seen the show and never heard of the original until this one, and I still love playing this, so I'd say it's worth it.

It is a bit of a short/simple (you can see there's lots of work put into it though) game considering it costs 14€ but I don't personally feel cheated because there's difficulty levels for everyone (even for the most demanding). I managed to rage on the Easy level though so if you are not too into platformers you might wanna prepare yourself for mild frustrations. Also there are cut scenes that might seem a little childish to some but you can skip them which is a excellent feature in that case. Overall the game runs excellent on this older computer of mine. If I have to think anything negative it would be the lack of volume control in-game but you can easily lower it manually from your computer.

reviewText: This is a great update to a classic game. Graphically, the fresh paint makes this one of the most beautiful games released this year (2013). reviewText:
The original was great, this one takes all the joy out of it. Every two minutes ( or less, literally sometimes just tens of seconds) your stopped so you have to listen to unskippable dilaogue, with no value (I.e. what each coin thats only used in a coin puzzle signifies, complete with then 30 seconds more, useless, dialogue with launchpad, repeat x8. Literally.) Screw up and die, and need to repeat the level, welp, now you got to listen to it al over again. Want to replay the game... same.

Ontop of it the gameplays speeds been dialed back. Characters just seem to float forever.

Buy shovel knight if you want some pogo action. I know you got the original voice actors, doesn't mean we need to listen to them over and over again in slow-mo. If your still unsure, watch TotalBiscuits review (with gameplay footage.) He was spot on.

reviewText:
So yeah, it's basically Ducktales from NES, only prettier. It's go everything Ducktales had, all the same stages, the secret stage and everything, as well as extra difficulty modes (or maybe the NES one had this, I don't remember, it's been a while). If you liked Ducktales, or never played it, then yes, I would recommend getting this game.

Fair warning though, there is a lot of lag and slowdown in this game. I thought it might just be my system, but it seems to be an issue with the program itself. It doesn't really affect gameplay, but the cutscenes are bad.

My biggest complaint about this game, though, is that I think they didn't get Fenton's VA back, and the person who does it doesn't sound right to me. Otherwise, yay nostalgia.

reviewText: This game is an amazing example of what happens when you put time and effort into the recreation of a previous generation video game. They took a lot of the original sprites and completely redesigned them, thinking about what the original creators would have done had they more bits/pixels with which to work. The voice acting and theme songs have been redone and polished, but retain all of their originality and are amazingly well done and nostalgic. The actual gameplay hasn't changed much, and I am thankful for leaving that mostly in tact but polishing most of the other parts of the game.\n\nOnce you start it up and hear that theme song, you'll know you've done the right thing.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
DuckTales: Remastered is a faithful upgrade to the NES classic. That's all you really need to know if you played the original way back when: loved it or hated it, DuckTales: Remastered is essentially the same game with hi-res sprites and polygonal backgrounds and a few extras for fans.

Otherwise, DuckTales is a good example of 80s-era platforming. Controls are responsive and the game has full controller support (I've used both an arcade stick and a standard Xbox 360 controller to play). The plot and dialogue are a little... kiddie, but that is to be expected considering the source material.

Nostalgia aside, I have enjoyed playing DuckTales: Remastered every bit as much as I did when I was 10 years old.

reviewText:
I have some blurred memories of this game, remembering mostly the pogo jump and the appearance of diamonds in places you pass through. But even if im not really fueled by nostalgia, i still learnt to love this game a lot.
The music is so amazing, that you will enjoy it no matter what (you'll enjoy it even more if you are into chiptunes like me!)
Gameplay is as simple as you can get, you jump, pogo jump and can do a cane swing with some static objects, and that's it, but even though the mechanics are simple the game is super enjoyable and memorable.
Highly recommended for plataform lovers and a must get for people that actually played and remember the NES version.

reviewText:
A wonderful remake of the 8-bit classic. If you're using Nvidia video hardware make sure you have the latest drivers (especially if you're running a display higher than 60Hz) so that the game runs at the correct framerate.

The voice acting (by 90% of the original cast) is spot on. As far as platformers go, this is a great blend of timing, aesthetics and music. (I could loop the opening theme music and music in the credits for days.) Using a game controller is recommended.

Highly recommended and a decent value at only $15 (or grab it for 33% off during a Steam sale)!

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Prepare to be injected with an overdose of nostalgia.

DuckTales Remastered, will carry you away back to your childhood. The Classic Capcom intro sent goosebumps down my spine and everything after it was not disappointing. Some minor gripes here and there.

There are hints of dubstep in some of the musical scores. Which can be overlooked, but really? Transylvania needs dubstep?

The game is a lot of fun and it holds up to the NES version in difficulty. You can spend hard earned money to unlock concept arts, character art and so on. If your someone who needs to unlock everything then there is plenty to do here.

I hope more remakes come out. Chip & Dale and Darkwing Duck would be excellent choices.

Above all I highly recommend this game to new and old gamers. You can't go wrong with solving mysteries or the possibility of rewriting history.

I give DuckTales: Remastered a 5/5.

For more reviews check out J&J Game
http://brutalgamereviewers.blogspot.com/2013/12/ducktales-remastered.html

reviewText: I love everything about this game.  It takes the feel of an old Capcom platformer, and breathes new life into the old formula.  If you're a fan of platformers, DuckTales, or even just solid gameplay, this game is for you.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
An exellent remake of the original NES title. The graphics are clean, crisp and colorful. A true and faithful remake of the original. Controls are spot on (see below) and the flow is good. Desipite the levels being a bit small there is still some challenge to the game.

There are some issues with the controls. Sadly I could not play this with my original NES controller (NES to USB) and there are several others having issues with the controls even though it does sound like it will work with any controller, it does not. My Logictech F510 and F310 work flawlessly.

Overall I'm happy with my purchase and I give it a big thumbs up to anyone wanting to relive or just re-experience the NES classic. The original still holds a place on my shelf, but the Remastered addition is truly a classic in its own right.
voteText: No ratings yet
